bibl.title: Letter from Leslie W. Weedon to Henry Rose Carter, April 12, 1919

div1.p: Weedon asks Carter if U.S. gulf ports should begin a campaign to eliminate mosquitoes.

div1.head: Letter from Leslie W. Weedon to Henry Rose Carter, April 12, 1919
div1.opener:
Dr. Leslie Weedon
EYE, EAR, NOSE AND THROAT
2ND FLOOR AM. NAT'L BANK BUILDING
Tampa, Fla. Apl 12 - 19
Dr. H.R. Carter
Washington D.C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Could not
the ports of Florida,
(& all Gulf & South
Atlantic ports for that
matter) supplement
to their advantage the
work of the Yellow
Fever Commission
C1
B23
by a properly directed
crusade against
the Aedes Colopus mos-
quitos. Our port
cities are anticipating
rich returns from
more intimate com-
mercial relations
with South & Central
America in the near
future, & it occurs to
me that unless the dan-
ger of yellow fever
is reduced to the min-
imum the fact of our
nearness to these infected
& questionable fields
might prove a mis-
fortune rather than
a blessing.

Any literature bearing
on the subject will be
appreciated in lieu
of a personel letter
should you not be
able to write me.

I have a few letters
you wrote me twenty
years ago (about), on
the subject of yellow
fever. I have learned
C1
B23
much from you
for which I am
grateful; I also
recall with much
pleasure your visits
to Tampa & So. Fla.
years ago- The days
when questions of
proper disinfection,
& what was, or was
not fomites, held
the boards.

With all assurance
of high regard,
